qas.question: What are usually analyzed by associating groups to them and studying the elements of the corresponding groups?
What did Henri Poincaré introduce when he established algebraic topology?
What topological properties translate into properties of groups?
What represents elements of the fundamental group?
Who first applied groups to other mathematical areas?
Which topological properties do not carry over into groups?

plausible_answers.text: it can be continuously shrunk to a point

qas.question: Why is the blue loop considered relevant?
What causes the orange loop to shrink to a point?

plausible_answers.text: The fundamental group of the plane with a point deleted

qas.question: What results in a finite cycle?

context: Groups are also applied in many other mathematical areas. <a0_0>Mathematical objects<a0_0/> are often examined by associating groups to them and studying the properties of the corresponding groups. For example, <a1_0><b5_0>Henri Poincaré<b5_0/><a1_0/> founded what is now called algebraic topology by introducing <a2_0>the fundamental group<a2_0/>. By means of this connection, topological properties such as <a3_0><b6_0>proximity and continuity<b6_0/><a3_0/> translate into properties of groups.i[›] For example, elements of the fundamental group are represented by <a4_0>loops<a4_0/>. The second image at the right shows some loops in a plane minus a point. The blue loop is considered null-homotopic (and thus irrelevant), because <b7_0>it can be continuously shrunk to a point<b7_0/>. <b8_0>The presence of the hole<b8_0/> prevents the orange loop from being shrunk to a point. <b9_0>The fundamental group of the plane with a point deleted<b9_0/> turns out to be infinite cyclic, generated by the orange loop (or any other loop winding once around the hole). This way, the fundamental group detects the hole.
